close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (full definition: fields worker_pool, worker_pool_size, master, itc, shutdown, listen_fd, tid, etc.)
type/definition of daemon->worker_pool elements (the element type, fields shutdown, itc, master, ... )
explanation:
To check whether the for loops in MHD_stop_daemon comply with the MISRA requirement that the loop clauses do not use or depend on objects modified in the loop body and that only the loop counter is modified in the third clause, the analyzer needs the following symbols and why:

- struct MHD_Daemon (full definition): the for loop condition uses daemon->worker_pool_size and the body manipulates daemon->worker_pool[i] elements. The full struct is required to know which fields exist, which fields may be modified in the loop body (worker_pool, worker_pool_size, master, etc.), and whether those fields could be modified by called functions. This is central to deciding whether the second clause (i < daemon->worker_pool_size) references an object that is modified in the loop body.

- type/definition of daemon->worker_pool elements: the loop writes to daemon->worker_pool[i].shutdown and reads daemon->worker_pool[i].itc; the exact element type and its fields (and whether those elements contain references back to the parent) are needed to determine if operations on an element can alter daemon->worker_pool_size or other objects used in the loop clauses.

- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (macro/function): used in the loop body to decide control flow. The analyzer must know whether this macro/function has any persistent side effects or reads/writes objects that are used in the loop condition (e.g. modifies worker_pool_size or the loop counter) — if it does, the MISRA constraint could be violated.

- MHD_itc_activate_ (function): called inside the loop body. We must know its side effects and whether it can modify objects used in the loop clauses (notably daemon->worker_pool_size or anything that affects loop termination) or the loop counter 'i'. Also whether it can longjmp/abort (affecting control flow analysis).

- MHD_PANIC (macro/function): used in the body when MHD_itc_activate_ fails. The analyzer needs to know whether MHD_PANIC has non-local control flow (does not return) or has side effects on variables used in the loop clauses; this affects whether the loop body can modify loop-control objects or whether the body’s behavior includes non-returning functions.

- mhd_assert (macro): assertions appear throughout the body. The analyzer must know whether the assert implementation can have side effects (e.g. modify memory) or non-local control flow, or evaluate expressions that could change loop-control objects.

- MHD_stop_daemon (declaration/semantics for recursive calls): the second for-loop calls MHD_stop_daemon(&daemon->worker_pool[i]). The analyzer must know whether calling MHD_stop_daemon on a worker element can modify daemon->worker_pool_size or the worker_pool pointer of the parent (or any other object used in the for condition), because MISRA forbids the loop condition to depend on objects that are modified in the loop body (including via called functions). Also needed to determine whether the recursive call could modify the loop counter or otherwise violate the single-counter rule.

- free (stdlib): free(daemon->worker_pool) is invoked after the loops. The analyzer must confirm free is not invoked earlier (or indirectly during the loop via called functions) which would invalidate the loop condition object. Understanding free’s usage helps prove that daemon->worker_pool_size remains stable across loop iterations.

- shutdown (system call): called conditionally in the body. The analyzer needs to know whether shutdown has any side effects on variables used in the loop clauses (unlikely) or can cause non-local effects relevant to loop behaviour (e.g. signal handlers) that might indirectly modify loop-control objects.

In short, to judge MISRA compliance of the for statements you must know the precise definitions and side effects of the data structures and the functions/macros invoked inside the loop body (especially MHD_itc_activate_ and the recursive MHD_stop_daemon), to ensure the second clause uses only objects not modified by the loop body and the third clause modifies only the loop counter.
